title.narrative: Community Based Sexual and Gender Based Violence Prevention and Response Program for At-Risk Refugees in Nairobi, Kenya

description.narrative: HIAS’ project protects and supports the underserved and most at-risk urban refugees in Nairobi, Kenya. The project incorporates the provision of psycho-social, self-reliance, and protection services: 1) To improve the quality of response and prevention of SGBV at the community, group, & individual level 2) To provide refugee child protection/legal assistance at the community, group, & individual level 3) To provide protection/legal assistance to PSN (including LGBTI refugees), to build self-reliance within this population, & to build institutional and community capacity to address their needs 4) To provide for the protection/legal assistance and psychosocial well-being of refugees at heightened risk by maintaining and running a safe house 5) To design and launch an anti-xenophobia campaign to combat an increasingly hostile reception to refugees and to enhance UNHCR refugee protection efforts.

To protect and support the underserved and most at-risk urban refugees through the provision of protection (including safe temporary housing), psychosocial services, and economic development opportunities. The target population is composed of victims of GBV1 (including men, women, girls, and boys); separated/unaccompanied minors; and Persons with Specific Needs (PSN) such as the elderly, disabled, and sexual minorities (LGBTI). Program objectives consist of: improving the quality of response and prevention of gender based violence (GBV) at the community, group, and individual level; providing refugee child protection/legal assistance at the community, group, and individual level; providing protection/legal assistance to Persons with Specific Needs (PSN), including LGBTI persons and their families, and to build institutional and community capacity and self-reliance among these population cohorts; providing for the protection/legal assistance and psychosocial well-being of refugees at heightened risk by maintaining and running a safe house; and designing and launching an anti-xenophobia campaign to combat an increasingly hostile reception to refugees and to enhance UNHCR refugee protection efforts.
